journal-meta.journal-title: Psychological Science in the Public Interest

body.p: Eli Finkel is an Associate Professor of Social Psychology at Northwestern University. His research examines self-control and interpersonal relationships and focuses on initial romantic attraction, betrayal and forgiveness, intimate partner violence, and how relationship partners bring out the best versus the worst in us. This research, which has been facilitated by grants from the National Science Foundation, has been featured in media outlets ranging from The New York Times to CNN to Nature. Finkel’s service to psychological science includes a term as an associate editor of the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology. His recent scholarly awards include the Gerald R. Miller Award for Early Career Achievement from the International Association for Relational Research (IARR), the Early Career Award from the Relationship Researchers Interest Group of the Society for Personality and Social Psychology (SPSP), and the SAGE Young Scholars Award from the Foundation for Personality and Social Psychology.

Paul Eastwick is an Assistant Professor of Social Psychology at Texas A&M University. His research examines initial attraction, relationship maintenance, and the evolutionary psychology of human mating. He recently was awarded a National Science Foundation grant to study how attachment bonds between mating partners intersect with hormonal influences on mating behavior. His research on the role of ideal partner preferences in predicting people’s desire to initiate and maintain romantic relationships received the Society for Experimental Social Psychology (SESP) Dissertation Award.

Benjamin Karney is a Professor of Social Psychology at the University of California, Los Angeles, and an adjunct behavioral scientist at the RAND Corporation. His research examines interpersonal relationships, especially marriage, and focuses on how relationship processes and interactions are facilitated or constrained by the contexts in which they take place. Currently, he co-directs the UCLA Relationship Institute and leads the Los Angeles Project on Newlywed Development (LAPOND), a longitudinal study of low-income couples. He also consults for the Strengthening Healthy Marriage project, a national experimental study of marital interventions for low-income populations, sponsored by the Administration on Children and Families. He has twice been the recipient of the National Council on Family Relation’s Reuben Hill Research and Theory Award for outstanding contributions to family science. In 2010, his textbook Intimate Relationships (co-authored with Dr. Thomas Bradbury) was published by W.W. Norton.

Harry Reis is a Professor of Psychology at the University of Rochester. His research examines the interpersonal processes that influence close relationships, with a particular emphasis on the implications of close relationships for the health and well-being of individuals and their relationships. He is past President and past Executive Officer of the Society for Personality and Social Psychology and past President of the International Society for the Study of Personality Relationships. He has served as editor of the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology and of Current Directions in Psychological Science, and as chair of the American Psychological Association’s Board of Scientific Affairs. His research has been funded by the National Science Foundation, the National Institute of Mental Health, the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, and the Fetzer Institute. Reis has received the Society of Personality and Social Psychology’s professional contributions awards and an award for Distinguished Teaching at the University of Rochester.

Susan Sprecher is a Distinguished Professor in the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at Illinois State University, with a joint appointment in the Department of Psychology. Her research has focused on a number of issues about close relationships, including sexuality, love, initiation, and attraction. She has been the co-editor on many volumes, including most recently The Handbook of Relationship Initiation (2008, published by Taylor & Francis) and The Encyclopedia of Human Relationships (2009, published by Sage). She has been a past recipient of the Berscheid-Hatfield Mid-Career Achievement Award for sustained and programmatic research contributions to the study of personal relationships.
